comments.commentBody:
The USAmerica is the only country on Earth that was founded by and for immigrants, of all persuasions ie.
For that reason alone we should be at least tolerant of faiths other then our own.
But remember that tolerance is putting up with some one or something. Acceptance means something more welcoming.
At least tolerance of those that are different from us would be better right now then the so called Islamaphobia.

What a marvelously 'thought provoking' column.  I thank you!  I have received so many e-mails concerning "Islamaphobia" and they are not only terribly upsetting to me, but they show too many thoughtless and hateful comments.  The likes of Glen Beck/Sarah Palin/Fox News barrage us with 'what we SHOULD think and do with their horrendous amounts of  lies, hate and misinformation.
Nick, you are truly a hero.   I always enjoy reading your stuff and the great work you do.  Keep fighting the good fight.
You are correct that fear is the main fuel of hysteria. That is why this mosque must get built. So that, we can look back and realize what a non-issue it actually was.

Mr. Kristof, the argument that goes "the Bible has nasty passages too" doesn't cut it, obviously, with those of us who are equally appalled by the barbarism of the Bible and the biblical God.  That the Qur'an is not uniquely barbaric is not much of a defense, is it?  In fact the book repetitively - to take one nasty detail among many - calls for infidels like me to suffer eternal torture (which it describes with sadistic glee).  I'm sorry, but any rule that I must think well of such a book and belief-system, or not criticize it,  is a rule I have absolutely no reason - save fear - to buy into.
Mr. Kristof, thank you for putting this all in perspective.

Most Germans were Christians. Most Nazis were Germans. Were most Christians - and let's add, Christians the world over - Nazis?
The Taliban et alia are monstrous; historically, the politicization of religion has often spawned this sort of fanatical, murderous and deeply heretical sort of garbage. Kristof's comments are correct of course, and our own sporadically vicious "Christian" nationalists bear watching and always have. Americans do not have a special immunity to historically redundant insanities.
Meanwhile, there's a tremendous joke that no one quite seems to fully get re the NY mosque controversy - this is a SUFI mosque. A very progressive, interfaith oriented Sufi mosque, one might add, with a mystically inclined and sweet-hearted leader, and as likely to be harboring demented anti-American fanatics as a Zen Buddhist Temple in San Francisco.
I understand that word of this nonviolent, nondogmatic and mystical sect may not have penetrated into the swamplands of Alabama, but... (writer waves arms vaguely, this country is ridiculous.) Pick up a copy of Coleman Barks reading his lovely translations of Rumi. Or something.
Beats "Onward Christian Soldiers."

Yes, exactly.

A similar phenomenon also happened in the 1950s-- fear of the Communist threat resulted in the hysterical hatred of McCarthyism.

Thank you for your column.
I support the Islamic Center in a luke warm way.  I cold be more effusive if there were an Islamic equivalent to the 442nd.

Thank you for such a thoughtful piece. I've read as much as possible on this issue over the last few weeks. I also watched video of Mayor Bloomberg's speech and every other video of every other opinion I could find. The frightening reader comments responding to all the articles and videos dedicated to this debate demonstrates that a significant number of people aren't interested in learning and gaining a broader perspective on this issue. They're more interested in 'right fighting', clinging on to one shread of information that supports their narrow perspective, proving that they are right, and that anyone who disagrees with them is wrong.

Unfortunately, a lot of these people have no desire to listen to factual information that could enlighten them and change or re-shape their opinion. So much of this boils down to education. I hope the historical perspective that Nicholas used in this piece opens some eyes.

We all need to denounce the ignorance, hate and bigotry that are ingrained in many of our fellow citizens. We are all responsible for speaking up.

Patrick Maguire
Boston, MA

http://www.servernotservant.com/

A Case for Human-to-Human Service and Civility

What if Islam turns out to be different from Catholicism?  I never heard of Canon Law being suggested by Catholics to replace secular law.  What if Islam is at its root a political philosophy linked to a religion.  What then?

Thank you, Mr. Kristof!

As you point out, conflation of Wahabism/Salafism, extreme interpretations of Islam, with the beliefs of the overwhelming majority of moderate Muslims, has much to do with hysterical American attitudes towards Muslims. Unfortunately, in nations such as Afghanistan, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, etc., Wahabism is so deeply entrenched that those who disagree with its beliefs (such as Shias, moderate Sunnis, Christians, Jews, Hindus, Sikhs, etc.) are routinely persecuted or murdered. I would flip the emphasis of what you said: We Americans have to learn to distinguish between Wahabis (such as the terrorists behind the 9/11 attacks) and moderate Muslims (such as those supporting the Park51 Center (the Not-at-Ground-Zero Mosque)). But, more importantly, moderate Muslims in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, etc. need to reject, condemn, and destroy the scourge of Wahabism.

I am an American convert to Islam. I recently started an email list with my friends and family answering their questions on Islam. The response has been great - I have around 15 questions. People have been fascinated by the answers and very appreciative of my effort. I encourage other American Muslims to do the same with the non-Muslims around them.

The fear and bias in play can only be defeated block by block, connection by connection. We have some with bully pulpits who could choose to stem the bad behavior, but they seem mute these days. If only programs like Glenn Beck's had a warning label like cigarettes, since repeated exposure to either is likely to produce dis-ease.

Bravo Nicholas! This article is very much needed at this time as it helps uncover some of the historical threads of intolerance in the US and the recurring issue of the unproductful,  unethical, and totally deadening "us" and "them" mentality. Hopefully your article will help in growing more research on this problem and generate possible openings to ending the cycle. Thank you very much!!

If atheism was more prevalent, we might not be having these types of divisive and unnecessary debates. But then again, if atheism was more prevalent, we might not have had 9/11 in the first place.

In today's world, we should question the need for religions first and foremost: religions erect needless barriers between communities and are the source of many conflicts, more often than not.

Oh, whatever...
Thank you for this concise and insightful post. Fear is the bane of progress.

I think America is a young country with quite possibly the least historic baggage in all Western democracies, along with countries like Australia, Canada, and New Zealand. That makes these countries more tolerant of significant numbers of en-mass new comers, relatively speaking, of course. If a chunk of new immigrants were to land in most European countries, year after year, then you would most probably see much more xenophobia in those countries than what Mr. Kristof cites here.

PS. Mr. Kristof and Bob Herbert of NYTimes, above all other NYTimes Op-Ed contributors, make me want to keep going back to read NYTimes almost every day.

We never hate what we don't fear. This may be fear of 'the other' or even fear of the stranger we worry may be concealed within ourselves.

How many homophobes fear homosexual tendencies within themselves? How much religious prejudice is founded in doubt about our own faithfulness?

No one ever thinks of himself as a bigot, and prejudice always seems perfectly well justified in the eyes of the prejudiced. To the bigot, his bigotry is always just common sense. While ignorance certainly breeds bigotry, well-educated people can also be strongly prejudiced. Few people have the faith required to never be afraid.

Saying that it is all about fear not hatred is to make a distinction without a difference.

Did you know that the first common use of the word 'terrorist' in this country was 200 years ago when it was applied to preachers who relied on their vivid and fear-inspiring pictures of destruction and damnation to gain adherents.

That is a sort of terrorist of which we have an abundance these days.

People who are afraid are more easily led.

And, the fearful are dangerous.

religious freedom in america has a long way to go. america won't elect a non-christian president or governer. lousiana's governer bobby jindal converted to christianity and so did nicky haley who is running for governer's office in south carolina.

this story indicates america's state of denial.
there is a great deal of bigotry,islamophobia and xenophobia in the opposition to building the mosque near ground zero and in the recent immigrant bill passed by congress,which stepped up enforcement along arizona's border.

I have a Muslim friend. He gave me a Koran, and told me not to read it critically, but to let it "just sink into" my heart. That was a bad sign, I thought.

I read it anyway. It is very boring. It's a bunch of begats in the beginning, just like in the old testament.

I hate all the desert monotheisms equally: Islam, Christianity, and Judaism. They've all been a disaster for women.

Thank-You
Oh yes you are so right. I was a part of a Compassionate Listening Delegation to Isreal and Palestine and stayed with a wonderful family living in a refugee camp in the West Bank (Al Arroub). They were wonderful warm people but what saddens me is as a first generation Italian-American that family so reminded me of my old Itgalian relativtives living in the USA. They were warm, caring and so family oriented. Yet so many Americans including some of my own Italian American relatives view them with fear and anxiety. We, through our media and fears are promoting this fear and it is so sad. Thank-You for reminding us. As a first generation Italian- American this country provided me with incredible opportunities. Please stay with the subject so we as Americans don't forget what this country has provided for us and not fall into the cycle of fear we worked so hard to break throught.

Mr.Kristof, the controversy over the Islamic center near groud zero is not about fear-mongering or any sort of phobia.

It has to do with respect for the folks who died in the September 11 attacks. Those attacks were made in the name of Islam. There is no getting around that fact.

Just because someone (or group) has the right to do something doesn't mean that action is correct or must be done. Just some consideration, that's all that is being asked.
But you are going out of your way to fan the flames with mis-information.

When a liberal feels righteous ... watch out! Non-sensical diatribes, like your columns in the NY Times will be the order of the day.

I am personally disgusted with the ignorant American Electorate. They react unthinkingly to any change to the status quo with fear and intolerance. The Republican Party has ridden this process to their success ever since 9/11. The overall theme of Republicans (being conservative) is to profess ignorance as to the outcome of any threat and just raise the fear of the unknown. The Electorate reacts with support of this outlook.

FDR was so right that we need fear only fear itself. All problems can be resolved by our people with a reasoned approach: learn about the problem, consider reasonable responses to threats and select a rational course of action. Observe results to measure progress in overcoming a problem, and modify actions to correct any missteps. This has worked for us in this country for over 200 years. Why are so many terrified of threats to our nation? We have overcome so many obstacles with excellent results. There is really no threat, today, that cannot be overcome. So let's stay the course and move forward with courage and confidence. The Glen Becks of today are diverting us with their programs of fear. It should be beneath us. It certainly tells us what they are trying to do to us for their profit.
As always, Nick, you are right on target. Why does a country so supposedly committed to diversity and acceptance so easily succumb to bigotry, fear and intolerance. Sigh!
